question_details.title: Will PEPFAR funding be resumed before April 7, 2025?
question_details.description:
PEPFAR, the President's Emergency Plan For AIDS Relief, is a United States governmental initiative to address the global HIV/AIDS epidemic. Launched by U.S. President George W. Bush in 2003, [as of April 2024](https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/fact-sheet/the-u-s-presidents-emergency-plan-for-aids-relief-pepfar/) PEPFAR had provided about \$120 billion in cumulative funding for HIV/AIDS treatment, prevention, and research since its inception, making it the largest global health program focused on a single disease in history until the COVID-19 pandemic. PEPFAR [has saved](https://theconversation.com/pepfar-funding-to-fight-hiv-aids-has-saved-26-million-lives-since-2003-how-cutting-it-will-hurt-africa-250413) over 26 million lives, primarily in Sub-Saharan Africa.

On January 20, 2025, President Donald J. Trump [signed](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/reevaluating-and-realigning-united-states-foreign-aid/) an executive order pausing for 90 days new foreign aid disbursements [including for the PEPFAR program](https://www.kff.org/policy-watch/the-status-of-president-trumps-pause-of-foreign-aid-and-implications-for-pepfar-and-other-global-health-programs/), pending a review of all foreign assistance programs. On February 13, 2025, federal judge Amir Ali [ordered](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/judge-orders-trump-administration-reinstate-foreign-aid-funding-now-rcna192168) the Trump Administration to resume foreign aid programs in place before Trump's inauguration. On February 20, 2025, Judge Ali [ruled](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-administration/trump-administration-not-complying-foreign-aid-amir-ali-rcna193092) that the Trump Administration was not fully in compliance with the order.

After a long bipartisan consensus about the program's usefulness, in recent years PEPFAR has faced [increased opposition](https://rollcall.com/2023/09/21/pepfar-reauthorization-debate-highlights-splits-in-gop/) in the US Congress, particularly from members of the Republican Party. In 2024 PEPFAR [received](https://www.kff.org/policy-watch/pepfars-short-term-reauthorization-sets-an-uncertain-course-for-its-long-term-future/) temporary reauthorization from Congress amid the increasing opposition. See for example [this report](https://www.heritage.org/budget-and-spending/report/reassessing-americas-30-billion-global-aids-relief-program) from the Heritage Foundation.

According to [The Conversation](https://theconversation.com/pepfar-funding-to-fight-hiv-aids-has-saved-26-million-lives-since-2003-how-cutting-it-will-hurt-africa-250413) on March 4, 2025: 

> \[A]s of this writing, despite a [court order](https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/69628254/21/global-health-council-v-donald-j-trump/) to resume funding, it remains entirely frozen, and most programmes are still shut down. The day after the court ordered the government to pay [nearly US\$2 billion](https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2025/02/25/usaid-funding-trump-administration-court/) it owes organisations for work already done, the administration revealed that it had terminated the vast majority of foreign assistance awards, [including some for Pepfar](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/26/us/politics/trump-usaid-foreign-aid.html). Details have not been made public. Meanwhile, the [US Supreme Court put a short-term pause](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/26/us/politics/trump-usaid-foreign-aid.html) on the lower court’s order to immediately pay the money already owed.
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before April 7, 2025, [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) report that funding for the United States President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), which is frozen ([NYT](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/24/us/politics/trump-hiv-aids-pepfar.html), [JIAS](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11851316/), [Politico](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2025/03/05/congress/graham-warns-trumps-budget-pick-about-going-too-far-with-funding-freeze-00213662)) at the time of this question, has resumed. If a partial resumption takes place, this question will resolve as **Yes** PEPFAR's funding levels are at least 50% of pre-pause funding.
question_details.fine_print: An announcement that funding *will* resume will only resolve this question if the date of the resumption is before April 7, 2025 and no credible sources as of that date suggest that funding remains paused.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**USAID: Goodbye to All That?  | Joshua Craze**
The Trump administration's gutting of the US Agency for International Development (USAID) has had devastating consequences for humanitarian and development work around the world. The agency's funding for foreign assistance was paused, and many projects were shut down, leaving thousands of people without access to life-saving medication, food, and other essential services. The purge of USAID has imperiled the very existence of the humanitarian and development industries, and without support from USAID, large-scale projects are unlikely to continue. The agency's history is marked by a tension between its diplomatic and developmental aspects, and its efforts to develop postcolonial nations have largely failed. Despite some bright moments, such as the success of the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), USAID's history is also marked by failures and criticisms. The agency's collapse has left a power vacuum, and China and Russia may gain the upper hand in the Global South. The consequences of the Trump administration's actions will be felt for years to come.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 12, 2025 11:05 AM
Source:[The New York Review of Books](https://www.nybooks.com/online/2025/03/12/usaid-goodbye-to-all-that/)

**Confartigianato Warns Entrepreneurs to Act with Caution on Catastrophe Risk Insurance**
Confartigianato Imprese Macerata-Ascoli Piceno-Fermo is advising entrepreneurs to act with caution when it comes to the new obligation to purchase catastrophe risk insurance. The association is receiving calls from its members who are being contacted by insurance companies and banks with various proposals, and is warning against rushing into decisions. 'We are receiving calls from our associates who are being contacted multiple times by insurance companies and banks, presenting them with commercial proposals that they claim are advantageous,' said Confartigianato. 'We believe that this is creating a lot of confusion among companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises that do not have the resources to study their individual cases and understand the adequacy of the insurance coverage.' Confartigianato is suggesting that entrepreneurs wait for clarification from the legislature, which is expected in the coming days, before making any decisions. 'We are waiting for clarification from the legislature, which will be precious in drafting a policy that is tailored to our needs,' said Confartigianato. 'It is essential to note that from April 1st, companies with active contributions and access to funding will not lose their benefits: it is therefore advisable not to rush into procedures.' 
Original language: it
Publish date: March 12, 2025 10:45 AM
Source:[Cronache Maceratesi](https://www.cronachemaceratesi.it/2025/03/12/polizza-rischi-catastrofali-troppa-confusione-imprenditori-agite-con-prudenza/1939892/)

**Clean Air Program to Resume in April with 10 Billion Zł Funding**
The 'Czyste powietrze' (Clean Air) program is set to resume at the beginning of April, according to Polish Minister of Climate and Environment Paulina Hennig-Kloska. The program will be funded by 10 billion zł from the European Investment Bank's Modernization Fund, which will allow for the program to be shaped freely for the next one to two years. The decision from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBI) is expected in March. Hennig-Kloska stated, 'I believe that we will receive good news in March. I have the first information that we will soon have access to a new budget for this program (...). 10 billion zł from the European Investment Bank, from the Modernization Fund, will allow us to freely shape this program for the next one to two years.' The National Fund for Environmental Protection and Water Management (NFOŚiGW) submitted a request for 10 billion zł to the EBI in February to finance the program. The funds come from the Modernization Fund, and the EBI's approval is required. The program was temporarily suspended in November 2024 due to concerns about its reform and the need to tighten the system to prevent fraud. The NFOŚiGW informed that without the suspension, there would have been even more cases of deceived individuals and embezzled funds by unscrupulous contractors.
Original language: pl
Publish date: March 12, 2025 08:27 AM
Source:[Bankier.pl](https://www.bankier.pl/wiadomosc/Wraca-program-Czyste-powietrze-Minister-podala-termin-8906123.html)

**Trump is cancelling a republican project to wipe out AIDS, putting millions of lives at risk**
The President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (Pepfar), a program established by George W. Bush in 2003, has been severely cut by the Trump administration. Pepfar, which accounts for around 70% of the total funding for the global response to HIV, has been included in the administration's attack on U.S. aid spending. The program, which was funding the treatment of over 20 million people across 55 countries, supporting over 90% of the use of pre-exposure prophylaxis to prevent new infections, and funding the testing of 83.8 million people in 2024, has been 'gutted' in its current form. The importance of Pepfar as a tool of global soft power and its bipartisan support had led many to assume it would survive the administration's reductions of aid. However, the program's decline was accelerated by growing Republican hostility, including criticism over the funding of abortions in Mozambique. The ending of U.S. support for global HIV programs is a disaster for those in low and middle-income countries, with a report suggesting that ending U.S. support could lead to an additional 565,000 new infections and 601,000 more deaths over the next decade.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 12, 2025 01:40 AM
Source:[Medical Xpress - Medical and Health News](https://medicalxpress.com/news/2025-03-trump-cancelling-republican-aids-millions.html)

**Why The Health Of The Most Vulnerable Will Suffer Under The Trump Administration**
The Trump administration's policy shifts on health and global health will have devastating consequences for the most vulnerable populations in America and around the world. The cuts to USAID's foreign aid contracts, which equate to billions of dollars in aid to fight infectious diseases like malaria, will lead to 15 million additional malaria cases and 107,000 additional deaths globally. The funding cuts for tuberculosis programs will disrupt drug supply chains and laboratory services, resulting in 3,600 tuberculosis deaths and 6,400 new cases. The President's Emergency Plan For AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) has been impacted, and if funding is not restored, about 1 million people will die every year. Additionally, the termination of the Health Equity Advisory Committee for Medicare and Medicaid Services will exacerbate racial disparities in healthcare, and the future of Medicaid remains uncertain, with potential cuts that could drop millions of Americans from the program.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 12, 2025 12:31 AM
Source:[Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/omerawan/2025/03/11/why-the-health-of-the-most-vulnerable-will-suffer-under-the-trump-administration/)

**Trump is cancelling a Republican project to wipe out AIDS  --  putting millions of lives at risk**
The Trump administration has cancelled the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (Pepfar), a program that has been instrumental in reducing the global HIV epidemic. Pepfar, established by George W. Bush in 2003, has been funding the treatment of over 20 million people, including 560,000 children, across 55 countries. The program has been a rare example of bipartisan support in the US, but was included in the Trump administration's attack on US aid spending. The cancellation of Pepfar is expected to lead to an additional 565,000 new infections and 601,000 more deaths over the next decade, particularly in low and middle-income countries where the program accounts for a significant portion of the HIV prevention and treatment budget. 'It has been a remarkable fall for an organisation that at the was funding the treatment of more than 20 million people (including over 560,000 children) across 55 countries; supporting over 90% of the use of pre-exposure phrophylaxis to prevent new infections; funding the testing of 83.8 million people in 2024 (up from 71 million the previous year); and was directly supporting 342,000 health workers across the world.' said a report. The end of Pepfar is a disaster for those in low and middle-income countries, and rebuilding a global HIV response less dependent on any single donor is essential.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 11, 2025 06:23 AM
Source:[Down to Earth](https://www.downtoearth.org.in/governance/trump-is-cancelling-a-republican-project-to-wipe-out-aids-putting-millions-of-lives-at-risk)

**Africa: Ending Aids, Malaria and TB Is an Urgent Imperative**
Ending AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis (TB) is within reach, but the gains made over the last two decades are in jeopardy due to the US government's potential retreat from global health leadership. As African health advocates, Olivia Ngou and Rosemary Mburu emphasize that it's the wrong time to step back, but rather to double down. They highlight the challenges in global health, including the US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) and the implementation of 'Stop Work Orders', which have already disrupted health programs in Africa. The authors stress that investing in health is a moral and strategic imperative, citing the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, which has cut the combined death rate from these diseases by 63% over the last two decades, saving 65 million lives. They call on African leaders to play their part in fighting major infectious diseases and support continued investments in international financing for health. The Global Fund's Eighth Replenishment, with a target of US$18 billion, aims to save 23 million lives between 2027 and 2029 and reduce deaths from these diseases by 64% compared to 2023 levels. 'It's essential that African advocates raise up their voices this time to ensure that our leaders don't step back from the fight against these diseases before the battle is won,' Ngou and Mburu emphasize.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 11, 2025 05:23 AM
Source:[allAfrica](https://allafrica.com/stories/202503110010.html)

**Trump is cancelling a Republican project to wipe out Aids - putting millions of lives at risk**
The US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (Pepfar) has been severely cut by the Trump administration, putting millions of lives at risk. Pepfar, which was established by George W. Bush in 2003, has been a major success in tackling the global HIV epidemic, with a 51% reduction in deaths and a 39% reduction in new infections since 2010. However, the programme has been included in the Trump administration's attack on US aid spending, and funding has been suspended. This is a disaster for those in low and middle-income countries, where Pepfar supports around 70% of the global response to HIV. The immediate challenge is to fund ongoing treatment, but even if new funding can be found, the knock-on impact will be serious, with an estimated 565,000 new infections and 601,000 more deaths over the next decade. The former head of UNAids, Peter Piot, has raised the prospect of countries like Zimbabwe and Zambia running out of anti-HIV drugs.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 05:26 PM
Source:[The Conversation](http://theconversation.com/trump-is-cancelling-a-republican-project-to-wipe-out-aids-putting-millions-of-lives-at-risk-251198)

**South Africa’s HIV/AIDS fight faces setback as US cuts PEPFAR funding**
South Africa's fight against HIV/AIDS is facing a setback due to the US cutting funding for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) program. According to the Department of Health's annual report, 95% of people living with HIV are aware of their status, 79% are on antiretroviral therapy (ART), and 93% of those on ART achieved viral suppression at 12 months. However, without PEPFAR funding, over 222,000 South Africans living with HIV, including 7,445 children under 15, face disruptions in ART supplies. UNAIDS estimates that 4,280 NGOs and 15,374 HIV response staff will be affected. The National Department of Health has released contingency measures to maintain uninterrupted HIV services, but the impact of funding cuts could result in an increase of 30,000 to 64,000 new HIV infections and 600 to 1,200 additional AIDS-related deaths by 2028. As Medical Science expert Jayshri Rangasamy notes, 'it is imperative that we closely monitor the situation to gain a comprehensive understanding of the true impact that the funding cuts will have on our HIV care and essential services.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 28, 2025 01:17 PM
Source:[briefly.co.za](https://briefly.co.za/editorial/opinion/210864-south-africas-hivaids-fight-faces-setback-cuts-pepfar-funding/)

**Pepfar funding to fight HIV/Aids has saved 26 million lives since 2003: how cutting it will hurt Africa**
The US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (Pepfar) has been a cornerstone of global HIV/AIDS prevention, care, and treatment for over two decades. Since its inception in 2003, Pepfar has saved 26 million lives and prevented nearly 8 million babies from being born with HIV. However, the program's future is uncertain due to recent political discord and major disruption. In January 2024, Pepfar reported that four nurses in Mozambique had used Pepfar funding to perform abortions, which led to a freeze on funds. President Donald Trump signed an executive order pausing all further disbursements and new obligations of foreign assistance funds for 90 days. As a result, Pepfar programs were severely impacted, with many organizations forced to lay off staff and turn away patients. The impact has been immediate, with people on HIV treatment unable to pick up additional medicine, leading to treatment interruption. The future of Pepfar remains unclear, with much depending on the courts and whether the administration implements court orders. In the longer term, Congress could seek to resume Pepfar to its former strength, though this would mean acting against the administration's wishes.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 04, 2025 10:54 AM
Source:[The Conversation](http://theconversation.com/pepfar-funding-to-fight-hiv-aids-has-saved-26-million-lives-since-2003-how-cutting-it-will-hurt-africa-250413)

**U.S. cuts to HIV/AIDS funding will be detrimental for vulnerable groups in Kenya**
The US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) has invested over US$100 billion in the global HIV/AIDS response since 2003. However, the program's funding is set to end in April, which will have severe impacts on vulnerable groups in Kenya, including sex workers, men who have sex with men, and transgender people. The PEPFAR-funded partnership between the University of Manitoba and the Sex Worker Outreach Program (SWOP) has been critical in reducing HIV prevalence in Kenya, with groundbreaking research findings that have informed global prevention strategies. If PEPFAR funding ends, it will jeopardize STI and HIV services, leaving key groups more vulnerable to violence, exploitation, and human rights abuse. The University of Manitoba's research team is calling on Canada's provincial and federal governments to step in and become leaders in global health and the fight against HIV.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[canadianinquirer.net](https://canadianinquirer.net/2025/02/25/u-s-cuts-to-hiv-aids-funding-will-be-detrimental-for-vulnerable-groups-in-kenya/)

**Comprehensive update on HIV programmes in the Dominican Republic - Dominican Republic**
The HIV programmes in the Dominican Republic are facing challenges due to shifts in US funding and political dynamics. PEPFAR-funded programmes, which were stopped, are now being resumed, but the process has been slow. Other activities, such as PrEP for key populations and Community-Led Monitoring, remain on hold. The new Global Fund grant, which started in January 2025, has not yet been implemented at the site level. The suspension of funding has raised concerns about Haitian migrants not having access to their treatment programmes, and the absence of USAID-funded staff and transportation services may impact service accessibility.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2025 03:51 PM
Source:[ReliefWeb](https://reliefweb.int/report/dominican-republic/comprehensive-update-hiv-programmes-dominican-republic)

**The Outlook for PEPFAR in 2025 and Beyond**
PEPFAR, the U.S. global HIV/AIDS program, is facing significant challenges that could impede its ability to fulfill its mission. The program's current short-term authorization expires on March 25, 2025, and Congress is increasingly looking for program reforms and ultimately scale down. PEPFAR has been affected by President Trump's foreign aid funding freeze, which has disrupted services and led to increases in HIV-related deaths and new HIV infections. The program has also been impacted by the reinstatement of the Mexico City Policy, which requires foreign non-governmental organizations to certify that they will not perform or promote abortion as a method of family planning. Additionally, PEPFAR's reliance on USAID, which is being dismantled, poses a significant risk to the program's operations. The future of PEPFAR is uncertain, with concerns raised by some members of Congress about abortion and increasing pressure on the program to demonstrate more concrete plans about its future.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2025 02:45 PM
Source:[kff.org](https://www.kff.org/policy-watch/the-outlook-for-pepfar-in-2025-and-beyond/)

**US Government's Freeze on PEPFAR Funds Sparks Concerns for Global HIV Patients**
Doctors Without Borders (MSF) has expressed concern over the US government's temporary freeze on the 'President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief' (PEPFAR) and other foreign aid funds, which has had an immediate impact on people living with HIV (PLHIV) globally. Although the US government has clarified that some treatment plans can continue until April, the key parts of PEPFAR have been frozen, causing MSF to be deeply worried. MSF's US office director, Avril Benoît, stated: 'The US government's freeze on PEPFAR funds has been over three weeks, and this is a lifeline for millions of people, and it's still full of uncertainty and concern. Although some activities are exempt, our teams in many countries have seen that many people have lost access to lifesaving care, and they don't know if their treatment will continue or when it will continue. MSF urges the US government to immediately restore all funding for PEPFAR and other critical humanitarian medical aid.' 
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 18, 2025 03:14 AM
Source:[Yahoo News (Taiwan)](https://tw.news.yahoo.com/%E7%84%A1%E5%9C%8B%E7%95%8C%E9%86%AB%E7%94%9F-%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%87%8D%E7%B5%90-%E6%84%9B%E6%BB%8B%E7%97%85%E7%B7%8A%E6%80%A5%E6%95%91%E6%8F%B4%E8%A8%88%E7%95%AB-021554330.html)

**US Freeze on PEPFAR Funding Threatens Lives of Millions with HIV/AIDS**
The Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has expressed concern over the US government's temporary freeze on the 'President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief' (PEPFAR) and other foreign aid funds, which has had an immediate impact on millions of people living with HIV/AIDS worldwide. Although the US government has clarified that some treatment programs can continue until April, the key parts of PEPFAR remain frozen, causing MSF to be deeply worried. MSF's Executive Director, Avril Benoît, stated, 'The US government's freeze on PEPFAR funding has been over three weeks, and this is a lifeline for millions of people that is being cut off, and it's still full of confusion and uncertainty. Although some activities are exempt, our teams in many countries are seeing that many people have lost the opportunity to get lifesaving care, and they don't know if their treatment will continue or when it will continue. MSF is urging the US government to immediately restore all funding for PEPFAR and other critical medical humanitarian aid.' 
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 17, 2025 08:09 AM
Source:[Yahoo News (Taiwan)](https://tw.news.yahoo.com/%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E5%87%8D%E7%B5%90pepfar%E8%A8%88%E7%95%AB-%E5%BD%B1%E9%9F%BF%E5%85%A8%E7%90%83%E6%95%B8%E7%99%BE%E8%90%AC%E4%BA%BA-075700838.html)

**MSF Calls on US to Resume Funding for PEPFAR Plan to Combat HIV/AIDS**
The organization 'Doctors Without Borders' (MSF) is calling on the US government to resume funding for the PEPFAR plan to combat HIV/AIDS. Although MSF does not receive funding from the US government and will not be directly affected by the freeze on PEPFAR, many of its operations depend on the interrupted programs. 'The uncertainty surrounding the US decision to suspend funding for PEPFAR puts the lives of millions of people at risk,' MSF said. 'The announcement in January to suspend support for the HIV/AIDS plan and the subsequent explanation that 'some treatment programs may continue at least until April' have caused 'confusion and uncertainty' about the prospects for continued medical care. Such 'uncertainty around PEPFAR puts millions of people at risk.' MSF is urging the US government to immediately resume funding for the full range of PEPFAR operations and other critical medical and humanitarian aid,' said Avril Benoît, executive director of the MSF US office. According to MSF, the consequences of the PEPFAR funding freeze are already visible in African countries south of the Sahara. For example, in Mozambique, MSF's partner organization was forced to completely stop its activities. In Zimbabwe, most organizations providing HIV services have also stopped working, disrupting, in particular, a program aimed at reducing the number of new HIV cases among adolescent girls and young women. The World Health Organization has also expressed concern over the suspension of US funding for PEPFAR. Its director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said on February 12 that it had led to 'immediate cessation of HIV treatment, testing, and prevention services in 50 countries receiving PEPFAR support.' 'We ask the US to consider continuing funding, at least until solutions are found,' Ghebreyesus said.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 14, 2025 08:25 AM
Source:[ТАСС](https://tass.ru/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/23139751)

**US Funding Freeze for AIDS Relief Puts 'Millions of People' at Risk, Warns MSF**
Médicos Sin Fronteras (MSF) has warned that the US government's decision to temporarily freeze funding for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) puts 'millions of people' at risk. According to MSF, many people have already had their HIV treatments interrupted due to the temporary freeze of PEPFAR funds, as well as all external aid for at least 90 days. Although the US government clarified that certain HIV treatment programs can continue until April, MSF expressed concern. 'Despite a limited exemption that covers some activities, what our teams are seeing in many of the countries where we work is that many people have already lost access to vital treatments and don't know if they will continue to receive them or when,' said Avril Benoit, MSF's executive director in the US. Benoit urged the US to 'immediately' resume funding for all operations, as the US government's guidance on the programs that will continue leaves out 'key areas of prevention, treatment, care, and follow-up for HIV patients.' Essential services such as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for all vulnerable groups, including LGBTQ individuals and sex workers, as well as specific interventions for adolescents and young women in high-prevalence countries, were excluded from the programs that the US will continue to fund. MSF denounced that the effects of the US funding freeze have already been felt in many countries where they have HIV/AIDS programs, such as South Africa, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and South Sudan. Additionally, MSF stated that it is unclear when and how even the limited activities that are allowed can be resumed, as the external aid freeze and suspension of work continue to affect other agencies such as USAID and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). 'These interruptions will cost lives and end years of progress against this virus,' Benoit concluded.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 13, 2025 06:01 PM
Source:[Forbes México](https://forbes.com.mx/congelacion-de-fondos-para-el-sida-por-parte-de-eu-pone-en-riesgo-a-millones-de-personas-alerta-medicos-sin-fronteras/)

**Embassy confirms Pepfar projects will restart  --  despite Trump's aid ban**
The US Embassy in Tshwane confirmed that projects funded by the President's Emergency Plan for Aids Relief (Pepfar) are exempt from President Donald Trump's executive order banning foreign aid to South Africa. According to the embassy, Pepfar has been granted a 90-day limited waiver, which will expire towards the end of April, for approved activities announced on February 1. The exemption falls under section 3(b) of the executive order, which allows the head of each agency to permit the provision of foreign aid deemed necessary or appropriate. Pepfar has committed $439,537,828 to South Africa for the current US financial year, but not all projects will be honoured due to the waiver's limitations, as stated by the embassy release, 'We have full permission to restart Pepfar under the conditions of the limited waiver Pepfar was granted under the humanitarian waiver from [State] Secretary [Marcus] Rubio.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 01:32 PM
Source:[Times LIVE](https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times-daily/opinion-and-analysis/2025-02-11-embassy-confirms-pepfar-projects-will-restart--despite-trumps-aid-ban/)

**US embassy confirms Pepfar projects will restart — despite Trump’s aid ban in SA**
The US embassy has confirmed that Pepfar projects in South Africa will restart, despite a ban on aid by the Trump administration. The projects will be allowed to continue under a 90-day limited waiver, which expires at the end of April. However, only approved activities will be eligible, and projects that don't qualify will not receive funding. The waiver excludes anti-HIV preventive medication, known as PrEP, for groups other than pregnant and breastfeeding women. The uncertainty and chaos caused by the ban have already led to the closure of many clinics providing HIV treatment or prevention services. According to Mitchell Warren, advocacy organisation Avac, 'the only true winner in the HIV response is actually the virus itself. The virus loves chaos. The virus loves instability. The virus loves conflict.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 07:59 AM
Source:[dailymaverick.co.za](https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2025-02-11-pepfar-projects-exempted-from-trumps-ban-on-aid-for-sa/?dm_source=top_reads_block&dm_medium=card_link&dm_campaign=top_reads&dm_content=maverick_citizen)

**Lifesaving Programs Still Halted Despite US Waivers**
Human Rights Watch has stated that despite US State Department waivers on suspended foreign assistance, many vital programs protecting and promoting human rights have not resumed. President Donald Trump's executive order on January 20, 2025, suspended $44 billion in funds administered by the US State Department, USAID, and PEPFAR, affecting thousands of programs worldwide and endangering the health, safety, and livelihoods of millions of people. According to John Sifton, an advocacy director at Human Rights Watch, 'President Trump's sudden suspension of US foreign aid has forced health programs all over the world to halt or curtail operations, including HIV prevention programs, and deny patients lifesaving medicines.' The suspensions have already begun affecting programming to prevent HIV, including pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV and PEPFAR's delivery of essential medicines to over 20 million people with HIV. As of February 10, the suspension of preventative programming has resulted in over 2,800 additional HIV infections that would not have occurred if PEPFAR funding had not been suspended.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2025 07:08 PM
Source:[miragenews.com](https://www.miragenews.com/lifesaving-programs-still-halted-despite-us-1405740/)

**Experts warn of HIV crisis as PEPFAR funds paused**
The US has paused funding for the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) in South Africa, leaving the country's HIV treatment programme uncertain. According to Professor Linda-Gail Bekker, Deputy Director of the Desmond Tutu Health Foundation, 'Just about all PEPFAR-related programmes including treatment, care, prevention, research and development have received 'Stop Work' orders.' The pause has resulted in the closure of numerous NGOs providing HIV and sexual and reproductive health services to marginalized communities. PEPFAR funding is crucial for South Africa's HIV programme, which has made significant progress in recent years. However, the country still struggles to meet the 95-95-95 goals set by the UNAIDS, with progress standing at 95-80-93 as of April 2024. Experts warn that the interruption of PEPFAR funding will have devastating consequences for the HIV programme and research in South Africa.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[health-e.org.za](https://health-e.org.za/2025/01/31/experts-warn-of-hiv-crisis-as-pepfar-funds-paused/)

**Laurus Labs shares surge 8% as Trump govt resumes funding for AIDS programme**
Laurus Labs shares surged nearly 8% on January 30 after the US government announced the resumption of funding for the US President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) programme. The programme, which was halted for 90 days, provides life-saving HIV medication to millions of people worldwide. UNAIDS Executive Director Winnie Byanyima welcomed the decision, saying, 'UNAIDS welcomes this waiver from the US Government which ensures that millions of people living with HIV can continue to receive life-saving HIV medication during the assessment of US foreign development assistance.' The PEPFAR program has been credited with saving millions of lives globally, providing billions in funding to combat HIV and supplying ARVs to over 20 million people across 55 countries.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2025 05:46 AM
Source:[MoneyControl](https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/stocks/laurus-labs-shares-surge-8-as-trump-govt-resumes-funding-for-aids-programme-12923861.html)

**Funding for long-standing AIDS program at risk: 3 notes**
Funding for the U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) program is at risk of being halted on January 27, potentially disrupting the provision of antiviral medications for millions worldwide. According to CBS News, Secretary of State Marco Rubio has ordered a 90-day review of foreign assistance programs, which will pause funding for PEPFAR. It is unclear if local stockpiles of drugs can make up for the delivery shortfalls during the pause. PEPFAR, which began under President George W. Bush's administration, provides billions in funding to organizations fighting HIV and currently treats 20 million people across 55 countries. As CBS reported, 'It is unclear if local stockpiles of drugs can make up for the delivery shortfalls during the pause.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 27, 2025 03:13 PM
Source:[Hospital Review](https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/public-health/funding-for-long-standing-aids-program-at-risk-3-notes.html)

For instance, despite oppositions, historically since its inception, PEPFAR has managed to continue through various political administrations due to these factors. The initial estimate is based upon the fact that over 90% of similar aid resumption cases tend to comply with court orders and pressure from both legal and humanitarian arenas.

summary: After evaluating the situation over two phases, the experts have revised their predictions about the likelihood of PEPFAR funding resuming before April 7, 2025. Initially, predictions varied, with probabilities ranging from 30% to 70% based on historical bipartisan support, judicial pressures, and existing political opposition. However, after reviewing recent developments, including ongoing administrative resistance, partial waivers, and continued political opposition, the revised probabilities decreased across the board. The revised probabilities now range from 5% to 55%, with most experts leaning towards a lower likelihood of full funding resumption due to the complex political and legal landscape.
